sections.title: Overview
sections.content: The ANS regulates involuntary physiologic processes including heart rate, blood pressure, respiration, digestion, and sexual arousal.

sections.title: Clinical Relevance
sections.content: Dysregulation of the ANS is implicated in many disease states.

sections.title: Exam Pearls
sections.content:
• Sympathetic = Fight or Flight
• Parasympathetic = Rest and Digest

sections.title: Definition & Classification
sections.content:
Heart Failure: A complex clinical syndrome resulting from structural or functional cardiac disorders impairing ventricular filling or ejection of blood.

1. Systolic HF (HFrEF): EF < 40%; impaired contraction.
2. Diastolic HF (HFpEF): EF ≥ 50%; impaired relaxation/filling.
3. Right-sided HF: Systemic congestion due to pulmonary or left heart pathology.
4. Left-sided HF: Pulmonary congestion due to left ventricular dysfunction.

sections.title: Pathophysiology
sections.content:
Systolic dysfunction refers to a failure of contraction, leading to decreased ejection fraction and dilated ventricles. The ventricular walls may appear thin and overstretched, leading to balloon-like chambers with reduced contractility.

Diastolic dysfunction, on the other hand, is primarily a filling problem. The ventricle becomes hypertrophied and stiff, reducing its ability to relax and fill properly during diastole. Ejection fraction remains normal because the ventricle can still contract, but less blood enters it in the first place.

Left-sided failure causes blood to back up into the pulmonary veins and capillaries, leading to pulmonary edema and symptoms such as dyspnea, orthopnea, and crackles on auscultation.

Right-sided failure leads to systemic venous congestion, producing signs such as peripheral edema, distended neck veins, hepatomegaly, ascites, and even generalized anasarca.

Compensatory mechanisms include increased sympathetic activity and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). These mechanisms initially help maintain blood pressure and perfusion but eventually worsen the condition by causing sodium and water retention, vasoconstriction, and ventricular remodeling.

sections.title: Management Principles
sections.content:
Management focuses on symptom relief, preventing progression (ventricular remodeling), and improving survival through neurohormonal blockade.

Core Drug Classes:
1. ACE inhibitors / ARBs / ARNIs
2. Beta-blockers
3. Aldosterone antagonists
4. SGLT2 inhibitors
5. Diuretics (for symptom control)

sections.title: Clinical Relevance
sections.content: Sacubitril/valsartan (ARNI) and SGLT2 inhibitors (dapagliflozin, empagliflozin) now form part of standard therapy per current heart failure guidelines (AHA/ESC).

sections.title: Key Concepts
sections.content:
Preload: The volume of blood returning to the heart and filling the ventricles.

Afterload: The resistance the ventricle must overcome to eject blood into the systemic circulation.

Starling’s Law: An optimal overlap between actin and myosin fibers leads to a stronger contraction, but excessive stretching causes failure.

RAAS: Plays a central role in the pathophysiology of heart failure, causing sodium retention, vasoconstriction, and remodeling. Targeting this pathway is fundamental in modern therapy.

sections.title: Exam Pearls & Pharmacology
sections.content:
1. The most common cause of right-sided heart failure is left-sided heart failure.
2. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) is elevated in heart failure and serves as a diagnostic marker.
3. ACE inhibitors are the cornerstone of long-term management because they prevent or reverse ventricular remodeling.
4. Digoxin toxicity is often precipitated by hypokalemia, so potassium levels must be monitored.
5. Carvedilol, metoprolol, and bisoprolol are the beta-blockers proven to improve survival in chronic heart failure.
6. ARNI combinations such as sacubitril and valsartan reduce hospitalization and mortality compared to ACE inhibitors alone.
7. Diuretics provide symptomatic relief but do not reduce mortality.
8. Calcium channel blockers like verapamil and diltiazem should be avoided in systolic heart failure because they are negative inotropes.
9. SGLT2 inhibitors now play a key role in improving outcomes in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

--- Pharmacology Detail ---

• Diuretics (Furosemide): Reduce fluid overload. Symptomatic relief only. No survival benefit.
• ACE Inhibitors (Lisinopril): Decrease preload/afterload. Prevent remodeling. Side effect: Cough.
• ARBs (Losartan): Use if ACEi not tolerated.
• ARNIs (Sacubitril/Valsartan): Vasodilation + Natriuresis. Superior to ACEi.
• Beta-blockers (Bisoprolol/Carvedilol): Counteract sympathetic toxicity. Essential for chronic management.
• Aldosterone Antagonists (Spironolactone): Prevent fibrosis/remodeling. Watch for Gynecomastia.
• Digoxin: Inhibits Na/K ATPase. Increases contractility. Toxicity signs: Nausea, Yellow vision. Antidote: Digi-bind.
• Ivabradine: Blocks If current in SA node. Reduces HR.
• SGLT2 Inhibitors (Dapagliflozin): Reduce hospitalization and mortality.

flashcards.front: What is heart failure?
flashcards.back: Heart failure is the inability of the heart to pump enough blood to meet the metabolic demands of body tissues.

flashcards.front: What distinguishes systolic from diastolic heart failure?
flashcards.back: Systolic failure involves decreased contractility and reduced ejection fraction, while diastolic failure involves impaired relaxation with normal ejection fraction.

flashcards.front: What are the cardinal symptoms of left-sided failure?
flashcards.back: Dyspnea, orthopnea, and pulmonary congestion.

flashcards.front: What are the hallmark signs of right-sided failure?
flashcards.back: Peripheral edema, hepatomegaly, ascites, and jugular venous distension.

flashcards.front: What are the body’s compensatory mechanisms in heart failure?
flashcards.back: Activation of the sympathetic nervous system and RAAS to maintain perfusion, which eventually worsen the condition.

flashcards.front: What is ventricular remodeling?
flashcards.back: Structural changes in the myocardium due to chronic pressure or volume overload leading to dilation or hypertrophy.

flashcards.front: Which drugs prevent remodeling?
flashcards.back: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, beta-blockers, and aldosterone antagonists.

flashcards.front: Why do ACE inhibitors cause cough?
flashcards.back: bradykinin accumulation in the lungs.

flashcards.front: When are ARBs preferred?
flashcards.back: They are preferred when patients cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors due to cough or angioedema.

flashcards.front: What is the mechanism of digoxin?
flashcards.back: It inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump, increasing intracellular calcium and contractility.

flashcards.front: What precipitates digoxin toxicity?
flashcards.back: Hypokalemia

flashcards.front: How is severe digoxin toxicity treated??
flashcards.back: With digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Digi-bind).

flashcards.front: Which beta-blockers improve survival in heart failure?
flashcards.back: Bisoprolol, carvedilol, and metoprolol succinate.

flashcards.front: Which beta-blockers improve survival in heart failure?
flashcards.back: Bisoprolol, carvedilol, and metoprolol succinate.

flashcards.front: Do diuretics improve survival?
flashcards.back: Only symptomatic relief.

flashcards.front: What is the mechanism of ivabradine?
flashcards.back: It inhibits the funny current in the sinoatrial node, reducing heart rate.

flashcards.front: What is preload?
flashcards.back: The volume of blood returning to the ventricles before contraction.

flashcards.front: What is afterload?
flashcards.back: The resistance the heart must overcome to eject blood.

flashcards.front: How does levosimendan work?
flashcards.back: It increases the sensitivity of cardiac muscle to calcium, improving contractility.

flashcards.front: Which new drug class benefits heart failure regardless of diabetes status?
flashcards.back: SGLT2 inhibitors such as dapagliflozin and empagliflozin.
